recipes.name: Spiced Dal Parathas
ingredients: 1 cup split gram dal, soaked overnight
2 tablespoons oil, for cooking and dough preparation
directions: 1. Soak the gram dal overnight in water.
2. Drain the dal and cook it in a saucepan with a little water, salt, black pepper, ground cinnamon, garlic, ginger, and green chilies until soft.
3. Allow the cooked dal mixture to cool for 15 minutes, then drain any excess water and grind it to a smooth paste.
4. In a large bowl, mix wheat flour, salt to taste, and 2 tablespoons of oil. Add water gradually to knead into a soft dough.
5. Divide the dough into equal portions. Roll each portion into a small circle, place a spoonful of the dal mixture in the center, and fold the dough over to seal.
6. Roll out each stuffed dough ball gently into a paratha, taking care not to let the filling spill out.
7. Heat a tava or skillet over medium heat. Cook each paratha for 2-3 minutes on each side, smearing with a little oil until golden brown.
8. Serve hot with sauce, pickles, or yogurt.

recipes.name: Traditional Scotch Egg
ingredients: 6 slices white bread, crusts removed, soaked in salted water
A small bunch of fresh coriander leaves, chopped
directions: Step 1: Hard-boil the eggs in a pot of water for about 8-10 minutes. Once cooked, transfer the eggs to cold water, then shell them carefully.
Step 2: Boil the potatoes until tender. Drain, then mash the potatoes in a bowl.
Step 3: Mix the mashed potatoes with chili powder, garam masala, chopped coriander leaves, and salt until well combined.
Step 4: Take a portion of the mashed potato mixture and flatten it in your hand. Place a hard-boiled egg in the center and mold the potato around the egg to form a ball. Repeat for all eggs.
Step 5: Squeeze the soaked bread slices to remove excess water and wrap each potato-covered egg in the bread, ensuring it's fully covered.
Step 6: In a separate bowl, mix besan with salt and add enough water to create a thick batter.
Step 7: Dip each bread-wrapped egg in the besan batter until fully coated.
Step 8: Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Carefully add the coated eggs and fry until golden brown and crispy, about 5-7 minutes.
Step 9: Remove from oil and drain on paper towels. Slice the Scotch eggs with a sharp knife and serve warm with salad and mint chutney.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a Traditional Scotch Egg, perfectly golden-brown and crispy, halved to reveal the vibrant yellow yolk and textured sausage layer. Use a rustic wooden board as the base, with a scattering of fresh coriander and chili flakes for color contrast. Employ soft, diffused natural light to enhance the textures of the breadcrumb coating and the creamy yolk. A shallow depth of field should focus on the Scotch Egg, with a blurred background of a warm, inviting kitchen scene, evoking a cozy, homely mood.

recipes.name: Cheera Cutlets
ingredients: 1 cup of finely chopped Cheera (leafy vegetable)
1/2 inch piece of ginger, finely chopped
1/4 cup of cooked and mashed potato
1/4 cup of bread soaked in water and squeezed
directions: Step 1: In a pan, combine the chopped Cheera, onion, green chilies, and ginger. Cook for 1 minute covered, until the vegetables are slightly wilted.
Step 2: Remove from heat and mix in the mashed potato, soaked bread, salt, coriander powder, and garam masala. Form the mixture into small cutlets.
Step 3: In a bowl, mix the all-purpose flour with 1/2 cup of water to create a thin batter. Dip each cutlet into the batter.
Step 4: Coat the cutlets in rusk powder until evenly covered.
Step 5: Heat oil in a pan and fry the cutlets on both sides until golden brown and crispy.

Employ a shallow depth of field to create a dreamy background, focusing sharply on the texture of the cutlets. recipes.name: Spiced Tapioca with Coconut
ingredients: 1 kilogram tapioca, peeled and cut into small pieces
directions: Step 1: Peel the tapioca and cut it into small pieces.
Step 2: Wash the tapioca pieces thoroughly and place them in a pan. Add enough water to just cover the tapioca and season with salt.
Step 3: Bring the water to a boil and cook the tapioca until it becomes soft.
Step 4: Drain the water from the cooked tapioca. In a separate bowl, crush the grated coconut, garlic, onion, turmeric, cumin seeds, and curry leaves to create a spice mixture.
Step 5: Combine the spice mixture with the drained tapioca, cover the pan, and cook on low heat for 3 minutes.
Step 6: Stir the ingredients to ensure they are well mixed, and serve hot with fish or meat curry.

recipes.name: Bhoondhi Raita
directions: Step 1: Combine the besan and water in a mixing bowl to create a smooth pouring paste.
Step 2: Heat ghee in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
Step 3: Using a slotted spoon, drop small amounts of the besan paste into the hot ghee, allowing them to form little droplets (boondhi).
Step 4: Fry the boondhi until they turn golden brown, then remove them with the slotted spoon and place them on a paper towel to absorb excess oil.
Step 5: Soak the fried boondhi in warm water for a few minutes, then drain and squeeze out the excess water.
Step 6: In a separate bowl, mix the curd, milk, salt, pepper, and chaat masala until well combined.
Step 7: Gently fold the soaked boondhi into the curd mixture until evenly distributed.
Step 8: Serve the Bhoondhi Raita chilled with rice, biryani, or as a side dish.

recipes.name: Vegetable Curry Puffs with Potato and Peas Filling
ingredients: 4 medium-sized potatoes, peeled and cut into large pieces
1/2 cup green peas, fresh or frozen
directions: Step 1: Boil the potatoes and green peas in a pressure cooker for 2 whistles. Allow the pressure to release, drain excess water, and rinse with cold water. Once cool, mash the potatoes lightly with your hands.

Step 2: Heat vegetable oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds and wait until they splutter. Then, add cumin seeds, curry leaves, urad dal, chana dal, chopped onions, ginger-garlic paste, chopped green chilies, and salt. Sauté until the raw smell disappears and the mixture is fragrant.
Step 3: Add the chopped tomatoes to the mixture and cook for a few minutes until they soften.
Step 4: Stir in turmeric powder, red chili powder, and garam masala. Cook for an additional few minutes to combine all the spices.
Step 5: Add the mashed potatoes and green peas to the spice mixture. Mix well and cook on low flame for 5 minutes. Remove from heat and fold in the chopped coriander leaves and lemon juice.
Step 6: Once the filling is prepared, lay out the puff pastry sheets and flatten them slightly without rolling.
Step 7: Cut the pastry sheets into squares or rectangles that are large enough to hold the filling comfortably.
Step 8: Fill each cut piece of pastry with the potato and peas mixture, ensuring that the edges are thicker for proper sealing.
Step 9: Preheat the oven to 200°C (392°F). Place the puffs in the oven and bake for 10 minutes. Flip the puffs over and bake for an additional 5 minutes until golden brown.
Step 10: Remove from the oven and serve warm with chili sauce, curry sauce, or tomato ketchup.

Incorporate fresh coriander and a small bowl of mint chutney as props, with a blurred background of spices and a textured linen cloth. ingredients: 1 medium potato, peeled and thinly sliced
A few spinach leaves, washed and patted dry
Oil for frying (vegetable or canola oil)
directions: Step 1: In a mixing bowl, combine the besan with half of the warm water and whisk until it forms a thick batter. Beat the batter vigorously for 5 minutes.
Step 2: Gradually add the remaining warm water to the batter, mixing well. Allow it to sit and swell for 30 minutes.
Step 3: After the batter has rested, add salt, chili powder, and garam masala, then beat the mixture again until smooth.
Step 4: Prepare the vegetables by washing, peeling, and slicing the onion and potato into thin slices. Wash and pat dry the spinach leaves.
Step 5: In a deep frying pan, heat oil over medium-high heat until it reaches a smoking point.
Step 6: Dip each vegetable slice into the batter to coat, then carefully drop them into the hot oil.
Step 7: Fry the pakoras in batches until they turn golden brown and crispy, about 3-5 minutes per batch.
Step 8: Use a slotted spoon to remove the pakoras from the oil and let them drain on paper towels.

recipes.name: Spicy Maida Diamond Cut Biscuits - Indian Snack
ingredients: Water, as needed to prepare the dough
directions: Step 1: In a large mixing bowl, combine the wheat flour, rice flour, besan flour, salt, red chili powder, sesame seeds, and cumin seeds. Mix all the dry ingredients thoroughly.

Step 2: Gradually add water as needed to form a soft dough. Knead the dough for about 5 minutes, incorporating 2 tablespoons of oil or ghee. Taste and adjust with more salt or red chili powder if necessary.
Step 3: Divide the dough into lemon-sized balls and roll each ball into slightly thick chapatis.
Step 4: Prick small holes in the rolled-out dough using a fork or knife. Then, cut the dough into diamond or square shapes using a sharp knife to create the raw biscuit shapes.

Step 5: Heat enough oil in a wide, deep vessel until it reaches high heat. Carefully drop the diamond cuts into the hot oil. Allow them to fry until they float to the surface. Lower the heat and continue frying until they turn golden brown.

Step 6: Remove the biscuits from the oil using a slotted spoon and place them on a kitchen paper towel to absorb excess oil. Once cooled to room temperature, store the biscuits in an airtight container to maintain their crispiness.

recipes.name: Raw Banana Bajji (Plantain Fritters)
ingredients: 1 raw banana (also known as plantain, cleaned and sliced longitudinally)
A pinch of Eno salt (or baking soda)
A small pinch of hing powder (asafoetida)
directions: Step 1: Wash and clean the raw banana thoroughly. Apply a little oil to your hands and knife to prevent stickiness, then peel off the outer layer and slice the banana into thin longitudinal slices.
Step 2: In a mixing bowl, combine the besan, rice flour, barbeque masala, Eno salt, hing powder, and salt. Gradually add water until the batter reaches a smooth consistency.
Step 3: Heat oil in a deep frying vessel over medium flame. Once the oil is hot, dip each banana slice into the batter, allowing excess to drip off, and carefully slide it into the hot oil.
Step 4: Deep fry the banana slices until the batter turns golden brown, ensuring they are cooked evenly. Remove and drain excess oil on kitchen paper.
Step 5: Serve the hot Raw Banana Bajji fritters with your choice of chutney or sauce.

recipes.name: Tandoori Roti
ingredients: Water, as needed for kneading the dough
directions: Step 1: In a large mixing bowl, combine the sifted whole wheat flour and salt. Gradually add water and knead until a soft and pliable dough forms. Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Step 2: Preheat the tandoor on high flame for 5 to 6 minutes until it reaches the desired temperature.
Step 3: Divide the rested dough into small balls. On a floured surface, roll out each ball into a round shape approximately ¼ inch thick.
Step 4: Slightly moisten your hand with water and stick the rolled-out roti onto the inner surface of the hot tandoor. Close the lid of the tandoor.
Step 5: After about 2 minutes, the roti will fall off the lid of the tandoor. Carefully remove the roti using tongs and serve hot with paneer kurma.

recipes.name: Traditional Indian Naan Bread
ingredients: A pinch of black cumin seeds (black jeera)
directions: Step 1: In a large mixing bowl, combine all-purpose flour, sweet curd, lukewarm milk, beaten egg, baking powder, baking soda, yeast, melted ghee, black cumin seeds, and salt. Knead the mixture thoroughly until a soft dough forms.
Step 2: Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest in a warm place for 6 hours to allow for fermentation.
Step 3: After 6 hours, knead the dough again for a few minutes and allow it to rest for an additional 30 minutes.
Step 4: Divide the dough into equal portions and roll each portion into a circle about 1/4 inch thick.
Step 5: Sprinkle additional black cumin seeds on top of each rolled naan.
Step 6: Cook the naan in a preheated tandoor or on a hot skillet until golden brown on both sides.

recipes.name: Cumin-Spiced Maida Papdi Crackers
ingredients: 3 tablespoons neutral oil or melted vegan butter
directions: Step 1: Toast the cumin seeds in a dry skillet over medium heat for about 2 minutes, or until they change color and become fragrant. This step enhances the flavor of the cumin for the crackers.
Step 2: In a large mixing bowl, combine the toasted cumin seeds, flour, carom seeds, salt, black pepper, and baking soda. Whisk the mixture well to ensure even distribution of ingredients.
Step 3: Add the oil to the dry ingredients, mixing with your hands or a spoon until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs, approximately 2 minutes.
Step 4: Gradually add water, a few tablespoons at a time, kneading to create a smooth dough that is neither too stiff nor too sticky. Cover the dough and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Step 5: After resting, knead the dough again for about 30 seconds and then divide it into golf-ball-sized portions.

Step 6: Roll each portion into a 4-inch circle. Fold the circle in half, and then fold it again to form a triangular shape. Roll slightly to flatten, then place each triangle on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Repeat with all dough portions.

Step 7: Alternatively, roll out a larger ball of dough into a thin 8-inch circle. Spray the surface with oil, then fold in half and roll until approximately 2 mm thick. Cut into desired shapes using a pizza cutter or cookie cutter. For papri chaat, use a 1 or 1.5-inch cookie cutter to create round papdi, sprinkling with fine sea salt if desired.

Step 8: Bake in a preheated oven at 350°F (175°C) for 12 minutes. Rotate the crackers, and bake for an additional 4 minutes. Flip the crackers and continue to bake for another 2 minutes, or until they are just lightly golden at the edges. Note that triangle crackers may require a few additional minutes to crisp up.
Step 9: Allow the crackers to cool completely and store them in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.

recipes.name: Fluffy Bhaturas
ingredients: 1 cup plain yogurt (curd), at room temperature
1 cup semolina (suji or rava), finely ground
1/8 teaspoon active dry yeast, dissolved in lukewarm water
2 cups oil (for deep frying), or as needed
directions: Step 1: In a small bowl, dissolve the active dry yeast with 1 teaspoon of sugar in lukewarm water and let it sit for 10 minutes until frothy.
Step 2: In a large mixing bowl, sift the all-purpose flour with baking powder 3-4 times to aerate it.
Step 3: Add the prepared yeast mixture and yogurt to the flour, kneading until a stiff dough forms. Maintain a firmer texture.
Step 4: Cover the dough with a damp cloth and allow it to rise in a warm place for about 4 hours until it doubles in size.
Step 5: Once the dough has risen, punch it down and divide it into small balls (about the size of a golf ball).
Step 6: Roll out each ball into a thick, flat disc (bhatura) using a rolling pin.
Step 7: Heat the oil in a deep fryer over medium-high heat. Fry the rolled bhaturas one at a time until they puff up and turn golden brown, about 1-2 minutes on each side.
Step 8: Remove the bhaturas from the oil and drain them on paper towels. Serve hot with curry or chole.

recipes.name: Rava Upma (Savory Semolina Porridge)
directions: Step 1: In a dry pan, roast the semolina until lightly golden, then set it aside.
Step 2: In the same pan, heat the ghee. Once hot, add mustard seeds and allow them to splutter.
Step 3: Add the urad dal and curry leaves to the pan; sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant.
Step 4: Stir in the cashew nuts and mix well until they begin to brown slightly.
Step 5: Add the finely chopped onions, crushed ginger, and green chilies; sauté for 2 minutes until the onions are translucent.
Step 6: If desired, add grated carrots or any other vegetables you prefer (like green peas or diced tomatoes); mix and cook for another 2 minutes.
Step 7: Pour in the boiled water and allow the mixture to cook for 1 minute.
Step 8: Gradually add the roasted semolina, stirring continuously to avoid lumps. Mix well for another minute.
Step 9: Lower the heat, cover the pan with a lid, and let it cook for 5-7 minutes until the semolina absorbs the water.
Step 10: Remove from heat, and stir in the lemon juice and grated coconut before serving hot with banana, sambar, or chutney.

Use natural light to enhance the golden hues of the semolina, creating soft shadows for depth. scenes.voice_over: Gradually add the roasted semolina, stirring continuously to avoid lumps, and mix well for another minute.

recipes.name: Dahi Vada (Indian Lentil Fritters)
ingredients: 1/2 cup urad dal, soaked for 4 hours
1/2 cup moong dal, soaked for 4 hours
1 tablespoon cumin seeds (jeera), or to taste
directions: Step 1: Rinse the soaked urad dal and moong dal under cold water and drain well.
Step 2: Blend the drained dals in a blender using minimal water to form a smooth, flowing paste.
Step 3: Add salt to the batter and mix well. Start heating oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
Step 4: Once the oil is hot, drop spoonfuls of batter into the oil using a large tablespoon.
Step 5: Fry the vadas until they are golden brown on all sides, about 5-7 minutes.
Step 6: Remove the fried vadas and place them on paper towels to absorb excess oil.
Step 7: Soak the fried vadas in warm water for about 15-20 minutes to soften them.
Step 8: In a separate bowl, beat the yogurt with milk and season with cumin seeds according to taste.
Step 9: Squeeze out excess water from the soaked vadas and arrange them on a serving plate.
Step 10: Pour the seasoned yogurt over the vadas and serve chilled or at room temperature.

Use natural light to enhance the textures, creating soft shadows that add depth. Style the scene with a rustic wooden table and a textured linen napkin, complemented by a small bowl of tangy tamarind chutney. Employ a shallow depth of field to keep the fritters in sharp focus while softly blurring the background, evoking a warm, inviting mood.

recipes.name: Spiced Tapioca and Beef Stir-Fry
ingredients: 1 kilogram beef, cut into small pieces
directions: Step 1: Cook the tapioca in boiling water until tender, then drain and set aside.
Step 2: In a large pan, heat 2 tablespoons of oil over medium heat. Add the chopped onion, grated ginger, and minced garlic. Sauté until the onion is golden brown.
Step 3: Add the chili powder, coriander powder, garam masala, and turmeric powder to the pan. Stir well and fry for another minute to release the spices' aromas.
Step 4: Add the beef pieces to the pan and cook for about 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the beef is browned.
Step 5: Combine the cooked tapioca with the spiced beef mixture and add torn curry leaves. Stir thoroughly to mix and lower the heat. Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes.
Step 6: Remove from heat and serve hot. This dish can be enjoyed as a complete meal or as part of a larger feast.

Style with a rustic wooden table as a backdrop, add a few scattered coriander leaves and a small bowl of chili flakes for garnish. Incorporate a textured fabric underneath for warmth, creating a cozy, inviting mood.

recipes.name: Fluffy Indian Pooris
ingredients: 1 sprig fresh curry leaves, finely chopped
Coconut oil (for frying, amount as needed)
directions: Step 1: In a mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of wheat flour, 2 tablespoons of sweet curd, turmeric powder, asafetida, and baking powder.
Step 2: Add ghee to the mixture and knead into a smooth dough, adding water as necessary to achieve the right consistency.
Step 3: Once the dough is ready, cover it with a cloth and let it rest for about 15 minutes.
Step 4: After resting, divide the dough into small balls and roll each ball into a circle about 5 inches in diameter, dusting with a little wheat flour to prevent sticking.
Step 5: Heat coconut oil in a deep pan over medium heat. Carefully drop each rolled poori into the hot oil.
Step 6: Fry until the poori puffs up and turns golden brown on both sides. Remove and drain on paper towels.
Step 7: Serve the pooris hot with curry or as a side dish.

Use natural light to emphasize the golden-brown hues and airy texture of the pooris, reflecting warmth. Incorporate a bowl of sweet curd with a garnish of fresh curry leaves in the background. A shallow depth of field will blur the edges, drawing focus to the pooris while creating a cozy, inviting mood. Include a delicate piece of cloth and a few curry leaves scattered around for added interest.

video_script.title: Fluffy Indian Pooris Recipe Tutorial
